Posts.Title: Any stage IV surviving 5+ years ? dorimak Yvette1952

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2019 05:27PM Mermaid007 wrote: I wish I had known when I had my primary that breast cancer in the breast alone doesn’t kill you. I wasn’t informed that it was only metastatic disease that is more dangerous. It was 20 years ago so didn’t have google then. I wish I had know it can come back as mets years and years later ( 16 years in my case) I would have insisted on scans etc in the years after treatment finished. I wish when I was diagnosed with bone mets my GP had given me some hope. I felt I needed to go home and “get my affairs in order” when here I am 4 and half years later

Posts.Content: May 31, 2019 02:33PM - edited May 31, 2019 02:34PM by Mermaid007 Hello, I had a bone biopsy to L5 4 years ago and as the vertebrae had also partially collapsed they filled it with cement. A procedure called Vertebroplasty. I was up walking ( stiffly) the nex day, so don't worry you will be fine.

Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2015 04:17PM Mermaid007 wrote: Hello, I have been on this for 15 years. My primary was 16 years ago and I had my ovaries removed as was only 39yrs old. I went into an immediate menopause and the hot flushes were sooooooo bad. My GP said there was an anti anxiety called Effexor that not only helped with anxiety ( which I had because of the cancer) but also reduced hot flushes. Over the years the menopause symptoms subsided but other life events made me keep with Effexor. Over the years my dosage has fluctuated between 150mg and 37.5mg daily and I have NEVER had any problems with it. I hope it is as successful for you. Best wishes x
Posts.Title: effexor patti4511 Romansma

Posts.Content: May 14, 2019 05:40AM Mermaid007 wrote: Hello Ladies, I'm writing from the UK. Briefly... bone mets in lots of places diagnosed 4 years ago. I also now have a liver met. I have been turned down for cyberknife to the liver met and also ablation on the grounds that I also have bone mets. They will only do procedures on the liver with a " curative" purpose, that is if I had liver mets ONLY. My oncologist said treating the liver won't extend my life as I already have it to bone. It's not clinically relevant. I realise I am under the NHS funding which is overstretched. I read that many ladies in the USA have procedures to the liver ( Y90) for example, even if they have bone mets. Do your oncologists think it's relevant? I feel that mets to bone only is better than having organ involvement, therefore I want to try and get rid of it. I would appreciate your thoughts. I do wonder if I was able to pay privately.... I bet they would do it
